Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2012 05:43AM steelrose wrote: Jejik, Bringing a new life into this world, under any circumstance, is not to be taken lightly. I lost my Mom when I was young, as many people have. It is a life altering experience and I don't think there is a mother on this Stage IV board with young children who doesn't live with the constant fear of having to leave their babies. I truly wish you all the best, both with your treatment and with your new baby. I hope you enjoy many years together!!!! And just an aside to all... Coolbreeze has been a constant target here for no other reason it seems than because she is very honest and outspoken. Why is that so threatening? Jejik has stated that she's not offended, and she goes on to explain her understanding of Coolbreeze's comments. It would be horrific if we were all little Stage IV clones, repeating the same "politically correct" jargon to one another without a disagreeable word. original thought, or honest opinion. Now that truly is a fate worse than death!

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2012 06:52PM steelrose wrote: Hi PizzaDad... I'm just catching up with you and Elka, and I'm sorry to read this latest news. The most important thing is that Elka's decision is being supported, her wishes granted. There is no right or wrong decision re. more treatment, no "giving up," or continuing to "fight." We are all buying time at Stage IV... we can't cure the cancer. But exercising our right to continue treatment if our bodies are strong enough or to stop treatment if we have had enough of it is still within our control. Honoring whatever choice is made is such a gift. You are the most wonderful support for your wife! I hope that the Halaven will stabilize her and give her more than a few months or years with you and your boys. No one can predict what will happen... we can only move forward with hope. Wishing you all the very best... Rose.

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2014 10:52AM steelrose wrote: Hi Missy! Well, I'm from California, but I absolutely love NYC. You will have a great time! Every time I go, I eat at least one meal at Juniors. It's near Times Square, in the theater district. It's authentic NYC deli style, and the food is very good! It does get noisy and crowded though, so it may not be ideal for catching up with old friends. Still, you must go and experience it, and if you like cheesecake... it's yummy! Posts.Content: steelrose wrote: I am scheduled for a partial mastectomy one week from today. My oncologist's intention is to radiate after surgery, and I met with the radiologist today who said he didn't think radiation would be helpful at Stage IV, unless there is major lymph node involvement. He said he didn't want to put me through it, but if the oncologist insists, he'd do it.  Is radiation uncommon after a mastectomy at Stage IV? I went through spinal surgery to remove a tumor there in Jan., and my liver lesion is scheduled for ablation in Dec. There is currently no other evidence of mets. I'm also having my ovaries removed at the time of the mastectomy. I appreciate that my oncologist is being so aggressive with her plan of attack, but I don't know what to think about the radiation. Any input would be much appreciated!          Dx 1/22/2010, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2015 06:44AM steelrose wrote: I complained about spine/rib pain for over a year. CT scans showed nothing. I kept complaining. The doctor guessed it was nerve damage from surgery/radiation to my spine in 2010. I tried everything to relieve the pain, but it only got worse. One year ago I had a MRI and bone scan, which also showed nothing. It wasn't until last month's MRI that my progression showed in spine/ribs. I'm now on chemo. Grrrrr… I'm a bit peeved that my onc. was so slow to order that second MRI, but maybe it wouldn't have showed up anyway?? Who knows. Onward I go… Be very vocal and don't let up if you're having pain! And ask for those MRI's and bone scans!!! Maybe PET's would work too, but I haven't had one of those since diagnosis. Listen to your body and demand that your doctor listens to you. Best to everyone… Rose.

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2014 10:59PM steelrose wrote: Hi Denise, I juat listened to your interview, and I think you did a wonderful job!    You emphasized how fortunate you are, how another stage iv person could have done the exact same things, and had a different outcome. I think this is so important to get out there... luck has as much to do with it as anything at stage iv. You also mentioned that you had aggressive treatment, and doctors who were willing to go for it with you at stage iv. This is another thing I feel strongly about. I would never have gotten to NED otherwise. We're trying to buy years at stage iv, as many as possible, and while there is no cure, there is certainly hope. You're an articulate lady, and you should be proud of yourself! Sending love, and best wishes... Rose.

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2012 08:06AM steelrose wrote: I haven't visited that thread, or if I have it was so long ago... I was diagnosed at Stage IV so I was never "not diagnosed but worried." In fact, I was never worried about my health until my diagnosis! Never imagined breast cancer, let alone Stage IV! I was always healthy, never visited the doctor (!!)... yes... a bit naive I know. I thought somehow I was immune if I just ate the right foods, exercised... you all know the drill. So in answer to your question, Ann... you better believe I wish I could get away from this crap!!!! But I suffer from a bit of denial, always have, and probably even on my death bed I will be planning my incredible escape. This board snaps me back to reality, and that's why I visit often. It's painful, yes, mostly because the names of all of you have taken on lives and personalities and I've grown very attached. When we lose someone it's both heartbreaking and very, very sobering. I would so much rather talk about fashion, vacations, good books, movies, coconut popsicles, denial, denial, denial, denial... and it is my ultimate fantasy that a cure is found and this board would be dismantled!!!! Of course then we could continue our discussions elsewhere about our fabulous, charmed lives... xoxo Rose.

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2012 09:48PM steelrose wrote: I lost my Mom when I was 12. She died suddenly so there were no tapes, letters, etc. I do sometimes wish I had known more about who she was as a woman... I can only speculate. But the mystery has allowed me to fill in the blanks, and my memories are warm and loving. My niece lost her Mom at 4 to lung cancer, and she did leave audio recordings behind. My niece listened to them when she turned 18, and it was so comforting for her to hear her mother's voice again. I don't have children, so I don't face this dilemma, but personally I think I would feel uncomfortable making video or audio tapes. I think I'd rather remain a mystery like my Mom. She left a powerful impression by not leaving anything behind.

Posts.Content: May 23, 2011 08:03PM steelrose wrote: ER+ means "estrogen receptor positive," which means that the cancer likes estrogen! So drugs like Tamoxifen control the estrogen in our bodies. I am on my second anti-hormonal, Arimidex, now. There are quite a few of these drugs that could help your Mom. And I barely understand my own healthcare plan here in the US, but I assume that you would be able to get a second opinion without paying a fee! You certainly should get one if you have any doubt about your Mom's oncologist or his plan!!!!

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 01:35PM steelrose wrote: Oh, Yan. When I first saw Olga's picture (on the "Olga" thread), I thought... I know her. How do I know her? Her pretty face seemed so familiar, and I ran it through my mind a few times... where did we meet? Well of course I know her... I know her through Yan! In the brief time I have been posting here, you and Olga were the first to draw me in. It was the sweet picture of you kissing her cheek that caught my attention. Olga's beautiful face beaming with happiness... the obvious love between you. I'm not a religious person, but I do believe in souls. Our loved ones may  physically leave this earth, but their souls stay with us. I love what you told your boys about looking in the mirror and seeing Olga. And how wise of you to have the social worker help them with their feelings. As someone who lost their mother at a young age, I know this would have helped me so much... talking about all of those complicated feelings that adults can't even understand. You are an exceptional man, as Olga was an exceptional woman. The fact that you found each other does not surprise me. I hope you will take the time you need for yourself, and find comfort in your sons... lean on each other... as you bravely move forward. Olga has touched me. Thank you for sharing your life. Rose.

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2011 06:05PM steelrose wrote: Dear Nil, I am so sorry that you have to deal with cancer... again... at such a young age. I was diagnosed last year at 45 and I thought I was young! But by reaching out and seeking support you have shown more strength than you know. There is a forum here for women in their 20's I believe,  and I know of another Stage IV lady who is your age (I'm sure there are others too but I haven't been posting long enough to be familiar). Anyway, the support here is wonderful from people of all ages. DO NOT GIVE UP YOUR DREAMS!!!! My dreams help me stay positive and focused on the future. Bone mets are treatable! I am having success with Arimidex and Zometa (soon to switch to Xgeva). Exercise, take walks, whatever your body will allow... it really does help my attitude. Be patient with yourself... one day at a time... Best wishes to you! rose.

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2011 07:52PM steelrose wrote: Oh I so relate to your post! Although I'm now a cancer patient, when I was in my 20's I was my Dad's caregiver as he battled the same disease. The best advice I can give you is to be sure that you take very good care of yourself, and that you maintain some sort of life for yourself. I was in school too when my Dad was diagnosed, and I returned home to care for him. I tried commuting the 3 hour drive back and forth for awhile until that became too much and I dropped out. Of course that depressed me even more! Because you've joined your Mom in another country, you've obviously completely uprooted yourself. Are there online classes you could take? Do you have friends where you are? Can your siblings help at all? You are so young and tackling so much... I guarantee that your Mom worries about you, whether she verbalizes it or not. She wants you to be HAPPY, and strong enough to go on without her. I know it's hard to imagine life without her... I was very close to my Dad too and I know how painful it is. But the biggest gift you could give her is to go on and live a full life. You're obviously a wonderful, caring daughter... I wish you all the very best! Rose.

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2011 09:28AM steelrose wrote: I had a liver ablation after chemo shrunk my one lesion from 6cm to 3cm. My oncologist kept an eye on me for almost a year beforehand, but no further developments in the liver so they ablated it. Chemo was slow to work, and they wanted to get the lesion below 4cm. The procedure itself was a little more difficult than I imagined (pain wise). But I'm guessing this was because it came on the heels of my mastectomy and ovary removal. The ablated lesion hasn't made a comeback appearance yet, and I hope never to speak of it again. Much luck in whatever course of action you take... Rose.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 4myangels RangerMom

Posts.Content: steelrose wrote: Ladies, this is a bit OT, but I need your opinion on something that's been bothering me. I went to lunch with a friend of mine a few months ago, and she invited another woman, who is a friends of hers. I've met this other woman before, and I liked her well enough. She's a young mother (30's), married, and she knows about my cancer. I was sort of ignored at lunch, which I understand because they were catching up. But then they brought up a woman, I'll call her Jill, an acquaintance of mine who had just died of cancer. I would see Jill on my walks, and one day as we passed each other, she stopped me and told me she had stage iv colon cancer. Very few people know I have cancer, but I opened up to Jill, and although we never shared much else about our lives, we shared that bond. We cheered each other on for months, until she disappeared. I saw her obituary in the paper in May. Her death really upset me. So back to the lunch... this other woman told us that Jill was a "very controlling woman," that she bossed everybody around, orchestrated everything in her life, until the day she died. She went on to say that she had an unhappy marriage, that her husband was cheating on her when she was sick, and that basically nobody liked Jill. This was apparently all told to her by Jill's sister-in-law. It was everything I could do not to flip the table! I was so angry, I could barely contain myself. I defended Jill as best I could, but I was just devastated and wanted to cry. I know it's just nasty gossip, and none of us really knew about Jill's life, but it hurt so much to hear this. Especially since Jill left two young children behind. And this nasty gossip was delivered so flippantly! Now I have to face this woman again at another event that my friend has set up. My friend doesn't understand why I can't get over my feelings about this incident. That yes, it was thoughtless, but Jill was just an acquaintance after all, and I should get over it. I realize my audience here is biased, but I also know that if I'm being a big baby, y'all will call it! I'm not usually this sensitive, but this hit a nerve. Thanks for reading this long post!!   Dx 1/22/2010, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2012 09:56PM steelrose wrote: Hi Barbara... I had very good results from Xeloda (in combo w/ Avastin, but I have heard of using it as a single agent.) I have also heard that the 7 days on, 7 days off regimen is more tolerable than the 14/7, which I had. You might ask your oncologist about this. Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 10:25PM steelrose wrote: Hi Heidi... This is very interesting. I'm on Anastrozole and my oncologist just told me about a new drug (recently approved... can't remember the name) to be taken in conjunction with the Anastrozole that basically resets things when your body becomes resistant to the drug. In other words, it prolongs your run on this particular AI. The SOLE trial makes sense, but personally I would worry about the break in treatment given that we're Stage IV. On the other hand, you're doing incredibly well and if there's a time to experiment I suppose it's now! Wishing you continued success with Femara!!!!  Rose.
Posts.Title: what would you do? Heidihill ma111

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2016 08:06AM steelrose wrote: Hi Becs, I had the Avastin/Xeloda combo six months after my diagnosis (spine/sternum/liver) in 2010, and it was a winning combo for me... shrunk all tumors on my first step to NED. I had more se's from the Xeloda I think... terrible hand/foot syndrome. I had some nausea too (who knows if it was the Avastin or the Xeloda), but nothing horrific that I couldn't handle. I also didn't lose my hair. Avastin is an excellent drug for so many, I was surprised when they yanked it soon after my last dose. I think it's hard to come by in the U.S. now. I wish you great success with this, and few side effects. You're an amazing young lady, by the way! Love to you... Rose.

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2012 01:59PM steelrose wrote: Hi Vickie... I sympathize with your pain and stiffness. I'm on Arimidex now, and I feel like I'm 90 some days! What you're describing could be arthritis or some sort of arthritic condition too. My bone mets (spine/sternum) were sharper pains, as opposed to aches/stiffness. How long have you been off Arimidex? Could it be a lingering side effect? Chances are very good that it's not cancer, but I would certainly push forward until you get an answer as to the cause. Wishing you the best! Rose.

Posts.Content: May 14, 2012 08:13AM steelrose wrote: We're all making informed decisions here as far as treatment goes and there are choices. Chemo and hormonals have proven to extend life, it's true, but not without consequences. There's a lot of grey area, a lot of variables, because we have no known cause or cure. It comes down to a very personal choice, one not to be taken lightly. And in the end it's certainly not a choice to be made by anyone other than the patient his/herself... however well intentioned these outside influences may be.

Posts.Content: steelrose wrote: I'm aware of only three ladies on this chemo, and am wondering if there are more out there to compare side effects, etc. with?? I've had three rounds and although I feel very lucky that nausea hasn't been an issue, I have a lot of annoying skin problems. My hands and feet are really falling apart now. No cracking/peeling yet because I'm applying lotion religiously, but they're inflamed and painful and walking long distances is becoming a problem. Can't seem to find the right summer shoes either… I think I need Uggs! Also, I have an outbreak of red bumps all over my legs and torso. No itching or discomfort, just looks like I have the measles. Dr. prescribed silver sulfadiazine, but it doesn't seem to help. And skin discoloration anyone? I have dark patches under my arms and in other weird areas:( Not really complaining because it's all so minor as chemos go, but misery loves company! Dx 1/22/2010, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Doxil! steelrose steelrose

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2015 02:40PM steelrose wrote: Sue, Yay! So happy your mouth sore situation is improving! Those red bumps were all over me too… my legs were completely hideous. However, because I had such a bad case along with the hand/foot problems, my doctor prescribed a steroid (Prednisone) and it really helped. The bumps are fading now, and my skin isn't nearly as inflamed. It was really horrible and uncomfortable! As far as creams go, I've tried them all. Eucerin (in the tub) works very well for dryness, especially on the feet. I also use cocoa butter, which smells nice and works well. You'll probably want to experiment and find out what works best on your skin. Hopefully you're seeing your onc. soon?? He/she may be able to prescribe something for the itchiness too. No need to suffer in misery!!!!! And pizza WILL be in our future. xo Rose.

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2012 08:34PM steelrose wrote: I honestly don't understand the hostility! I read the alternative forums... what treatments are people trying and what are their theories? There is no known cause or cure, only speculation, so it's difficult to completely dismiss anything at this point. The clues are there... between the conventional and the alternative... but the scientists haven't put them together yet. As to why people seek alt treatments, I suppose the answers are as varied as our individual cancers. Personally, conventional treatment brought me to NED and I'm very grateful for that. But I like to know that I have options! Stopping treatment is also an option and I certainly wouldn't want to be judged for that.

Posts.Content: steelrose wrote: I've hesitated to post about this, mainly because I feel like I should be grateful that my cancer is stable after six and a half years at Stage IV, and also because I don't want to scare anybody. After progression last May, I went on chemo (Doxil) until October '15. Scans were good, and I switched to Ibrance/Aromasin in Nov. with good results. In April '16 I developed neuropathy and started having trouble walking. This got worse and I went to the emergency room on May 27, fearing that the cancer was compressing my spinal cord again. Well, after countless scans and tests including a brain MRI, lumbar puncture, spinal MRI... you all know the drill... I was clear for cancer. So the neurologist has diagnosed me with CIDP, some weird disorder that I don't even understand. But he's not 100% sure this is the problem. Still, I've had four IVIG treatments for this with no improvement so far. In fact I think I'm worse! I can barely walk even with a walker, I have to lay down after the simplest tasks, and I haven't driven or hardly left the house since early June. I'm flat out miserable. This is not quality of life!!! All the while I'm convinced that the Ibrance/Aromasin is the culprit, despite my oncologist's denial. She briefly took me off both drugs before I was diagnosed with CIDP, with no improvement so I'm back on both. The Aromasin seems to cripple me even more with severe joint pain. I'm thinking about quitting both drugs and maybe going on a milder anti-hormonal to give my body a break. Any ideas what might be tolerable? What would you do? Thanks for reading this, and sorry for my whining. I just can't believe that cancer isn't the problem here... Rose. Dx 1/22/2010, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Guess I won't do THAT again!! Lynn1 china

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2010 11:48AM steelrose wrote: Boy, do I relate to your post! I'm also single, 46, and extremely independent. I do have a wonderful partner, who has been with me for 18 years, and he has been very supportive.  When I was diagnosed in Jan. I had spinal surgery and they weren't sure I'd be able to walk again. I was absolutely terrified of being an invalid and dependent on a caregiver for whatever time I had left. But with my partner's help, I learned to walk again and am so grateful to be back on my feet! I couldn't have done it without his love and support.  I think the important thing to remember is that our loved ones feel perhaps even more helpless than we do. I know how hard it is to accept that we even need help, let alone accept it. But the one thing that cancer has taught me, early on, is that there are some wonderful, compassionate people out there. And if I let go just a little bit, let them pick up a bit of slack, we both feel better. Like you, I often get overwhelmed but I try to counteract that with as much private time as the day will allow, to do the things that calm me, ALONE. I wish you the best!

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2013 09:11AM steelrose wrote: Hi George... I'm very sorry that you and your wife are dealing with this. I can address the Avastin question. My diagnosis was the same as your wife's, with mets to bones and liver. I also was on the same Xeloda/Avastin combo, and it worked extremely well for me. They were talking about pulling the drug in the US right before I finished treatment, and it made me nervous! All of my tumors were reduced by half and/or eliminated with Xeloda/Avastin, and I am currently in remission (since Jan. 2011). Of course, we all react differently to these drugs, but I certainly hope that your wife has excellent results! One thing you might keep in mind with Xeloda... I was on the 14 day on/7 day off cycle too, but others have been on a 7/7 cycle, and the side effects weren't as difficult. You might ask the doctor about this. I wish you and your wife all the very best! Please let us know how she is doing. Rose.

Posts.Content: steelrose wrote: Dear Ladies, I was diagnosed Stage IV with mets to bones and liver on Jan. 22, 2010. In one year I have gone from not knowing if I would ever walk again to, as of yesterday, being very much on my feet and NED!!!! I cannot express how much this forum has meant to me. I didn't join until Nov. but I spent many long months reading your posts and following your stories. You have all been such great inspirations...  I can honestly say I couldn't have made it through to this point without you. So a big THANK YOU for your support, your honesty, and for giving me hope for the future. We are truly in this together, for better or for worse. No one is alone! Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2012 02:16AM steelrose wrote: Hi Teri, I'm so sorry you're facing these tough decisions. My father had bc too... diagnosed at 67. When the doctors learned of my family history, they strongly recommended ovary removal. And I did have my ovaries removed when they removed my breast tumor. Honestly, it wasn't a terrible operation and I recovered quickly. The early menopause isn't fun, but neither is cancer! Because I was diagnosed at Stage IV, I really didn't have much time to worry about my ovaries because there were much bigger issues. I never struggled with the decision because it was simply necessary in my mind. I'm so glad that your cancer was caught early but I do understand that it makes your decisions more complicated. You were just diagnosed... so take a deep breath... and do lots of research! This website is a wonderful place to gather information. Don't let the doctors talk you into anything you're not comfortable with!!!! You'll make an informed decision and that decision will be yours. Wishing you all the best! Rose.

Posts.Content: steelrose wrote: Hi everyone. I've been having pain in my right breast, ribs, and back for about six months. It's become pretty intense, and no pain medication seems to help. I dread bedtime, because I'm so uncomfortable laying down. The pain seems worse at night.  I've had an MRI, CT scan, and bone scan that showed some edema in the back and ribs, but nothing is visible to me. I had surgery for spinal mets in 2010, followed by radiation, and a breast reduction on the right side after a lumpectomy on my left breast, also in 2010. Two or three nodes were removed. I wonder if anyone else has experienced breast or truncal lymphedema on the opposite side of the effected breast? I seem to have many of the symptoms... a burning, tingling sensation, fullness and pain in the breast, ribs, and back... of course, I feared more mets but the edema was the only thing that showed up on the scans. I think it may be time to get a referral for lymphedema? Does anything help with this pain? Thank you for any input! Rose.  Dx 1/22/2010, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

In my mind, this whole thing is not so much about Amy Robach as it is about the media's spin on everything. Everyone's a "hero," a "survivor," a "first responder," "America Strong!!!" The US really does have a bad case of this. We "kick cancer's butt," we're "tough," we're winners! God, it's exhausting. Amy Robach is just the latest victim. Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2014 11:44AM steelrose wrote: Karen, I'm sorry you have to deal with skin mets in addition to other problems. Of course, it's a minor thing on the mets scale, but the visual reminder isn't fun! I don't know much about skin mets, but mine look like small blisters. As Padiddle said, there are different types of skin mets. I hope that yours don't cause too much discomfort, and that they will disappear with treatment! Padiddle, I've tried over-the-counter pain meds, but they don't seem to touch the rib pain. I may ask for an x-ray, even though I just had a CT scan! Between the skin mets, "radiation recall," and rib pain... well, more questions than answers, and it's making me a bit crazy. Plus, I'm sitting up to sleep at night because of the ribs. I'm with you on the narcotics... I'd like to save the big guns for when I really need them. Hope you find some relief and soon! MDtoMom, Happy that radiation worked on your skin mets! Hopefully they will never return! I noticed that you are diagnosed with IBC. I suspected I might have IBC before my biopsy showed the same pathology as my original diagnosis. There are differences between IBC and skin mets, but sometimes it's hard to tell (at least for me!). I wish you the best! I do realize that skin mets are a minor concern in the big, stage iv picture, but thank you all for keeping this thread alive! As I've said before, without you amazing ladies I'd be so lost! Love to all... Rose.

Posts.Title: I'm Going to Disney World! Maybe You Can Too! TarheelMichelle Rosevalley

Posts.Content: steelrose wrote: Hi ladies... Well, I'm approaching my five year mark with Stage IV in Jan. I feel incredibly lucky to have done so well, considering how I started out. But I'm feeling very shaky and emotional as I get ready for my CT scan tomorrow. Part of this is the overwhelming feelings that the holidays bring... I've had lots of loss in December that I associate with this time of year. But I've also been having a lot of pain in my back and ribs, which has been going on for awhile, and my doctor feels is nerve damage from spinal surgery and rads combined with the Arimidex/Faslodex combo I'm on. I sure hope she's right! Anyway, any good thoughts and energy tomorrow is most welcome. I'm usually pretty cool about scans, but not so much this time! Wishing you happy holidays with your loved ones. I appreciate you all so very much! Rose. Dx 1/22/2010, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Scan tomorrow... arghhhh! steelrose RonnieKay

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2014 11:18PM steelrose wrote: NED!!!! I'm so overwhelmed, after what was an exhausting day. I couldn't even lay on the CT scan bed because of this nasty rib pain... I was terrified that the cancer was back. But it looks like it may be nerve damage from surgery plus the radiation. It goes to show that it isn't always cancer causing us pain! The oncologist is prescribing a low dose steroid to see if we can reduce the inflammation in the ribs/spine. I can't thank you all enough for your well wishes... it worked! And Terri and Smiley, please let us know how your scans go... I will be thinking of you... Rose.

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2011 03:57AM steelrose wrote: I was diagnosed with Stage IV, mets to spine, sternum, and liver. After chemo my breast tumor shrunk by half. It was a large tumor, and I had a "large lumpectomy" or "partial mastectomy" last December. It makes such a difference to me psychologically, not having that primary tumor there! I'm glad more oncologists are taking this route with stage IV patients. Best of luck, whatever you choose to do! Rose.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy even at stage IV??? mommyx3 MJLToday

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2011 01:42AM steelrose wrote: I started out on Tamoxifen and was stable on it, but because I had liver involvement my oncologist switched me to chemo. If your Mom is strongly ER+ and only has bone mets, switching to another hormonal sounds reasonable. I had radiation to my spine as well, which helped. I wish your Mom all the best! Rose.

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2013 10:33AM steelrose wrote: Oh ugh, Judie. Well, I can't comment on the port removal, but as far as the infection goes, I had IV antibiotics pumped into me for about a month after leaving the hospital. I developed a couple of infections after surgery, and those infectious disease doctors don't mess around! So don't be surprised if you're on antibiotics for awhile. I toted my bag around, and learned how to change it, etc. A happy side effect of the antibiotics is that my skin and hair had never been softer! Sending love and best wishes for a speedy recovery! Rose.

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2011 07:37PM steelrose wrote: Sue... I'm very glad you didn't give up... I'm only sorry that it took so darn long to get to this point. This is very precious time, and I blame your medical team for this mess. It is very, very wise of you to start again with a new doctor!!!! At Stage IV you need someone who is determined to fight with and for you and who will stay on top of EVERYTHING.  I am sorry that your son had a hateful reaction to your news, but hate is fear as far as I'm concerned. And although his reaction must sadden you, I am certain that he must be very afraid. Give all of your kids time to let this news sink in. It takes awhile to process, as you know. I hope you are able to rest and regroup... we are all here for you! xoxo Rose.
Posts.Title: I Guess It Was the Right Time 37antiques Reneepals

Posts.Content: May 7, 2012 12:57AM steelrose wrote: Oh Tiffany, I'm so sorry about your Mom. I had a very similar situation with my spine at T-4/T-5 and in my case I couldn't walk and had to have surgery. Is your Mom a candidate for surgery? It can be a tricky situation, given the close proximity to the spinal cord. I had rads too, which helped me so much. I'm glad that your Mom isn't experiencing too much pain in her back... amazing! I also had a liver tumor but no jaundice. I do know that the liver is very tough and it takes a lot to shut it down. I hope that her treatments will be very effective and that your Mom will be feeling better soon. You sound like a wonderful daughter... your positive presence will be very comforting! Please keep us posted! Love to you... Rose.

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2014 01:14PM steelrose wrote: Mary-Lou, That's an awful shock, and it will take time to adjust. But please know that there is hope for years ahead! I was diagnosed at stage iv in 2010, with mets to bones and liver. I was put on Xeloda (I believe that might be the "oral chemo" you're referring to), and I was NED (no evidence of active disease) for three years following that. So as scary as this all is, take it one day at a time. We're here for you! Rose.
